titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the General Photograph Collection: Portraits MSS.PHOTO.0100

publicationstmt.publisher: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2016-11-15 15:16:56 -0800.

repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

did.unittitle: Portraits (General Photograph Collection)
did.abstract: Miscellaneous collection spanning more than a century of portrait photographs depicting over 400 notable people, in many cases signed or inscribed by them.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [identification of item], Portraits (General Photograph Collection) (MSS PHOTO 0100). Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Note that material must be requested at least 36 hours in advance of intended use.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While Special Collections is the owner of the physical and digital items, permission to examine collection materials is not an authorization to publish. These materials are made available for use in research, teaching, and private study. Any transmission or reproduction beyond that allowed by fair use requires permission from the owners of rights, heir(s) or assigns.
Some material is believed to be in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use of public domain materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is not in alphabetical order. Some subjects have more than one folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Spanning one hundred years, this artificial collection of portraits, snapshots, and group photographs features a calvacade of notable figures, including politicians, military leaders, heads of state, journalists, authors, poets, scientists (especially professors of physics, astronomy, and mathematics), explorers, pioneers, labor leaders, musicians, and artists. The identity of some subjects is not always confirmed. Some names do not appear on the print and were from an unknown external source. Others remain unidentified. The majority of photographs are signed (i.e. autographed) or inscribed (used to describe a note to someone in particular). Some have stamps and other notes contemporary to the print and later, including old SUL call numbers. These are not always noted or transcribed. The photographer or studio and its geographic location has been transcribed when known. Most prints are believed to be original, but there a few older copy prints. While most prints are typical early 20th century prints in various mounts, there are also many older cartes-de-visite and cabinet cards, and one Polaroid circa 1980-1983.

This collection was assembled over the life of Stanford Special Collections and includes multiple accessions and donors. Many of them (perhaps a third) came from the famous studio Harris & Ewing and are frequently inscribed to the firm's Martha Ewing, implying that she may have donated them herself. Another significant source of photographs is Stanford faculty, including Frederick Edward Brasch, Melville Best Anderson, Edith R. Mirrielees, and Mary Sheldon Barnes. Some photographs were removed from their original archival papers. For example, mixed throughout the collection are several images from Columbia and the gold mining region of California's Tuolumne County; these are likely separated from the Otheto Weston Gold Country Collection, ca. 1849-1944 (M0029): https://searchworks.stanford.edu/view/4082747. All of these sources are noted where indicated.

M.A. Banahan (now Brady) 1862 [Sewell's photograph, Sonora]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Banahan (1849-1925) was one of two daughters born to Mary Teresa Kilduff who emigrated to Sonora, California from Ireland with her children after the death of her husband. Margaret married Matthew T. Brady of Columbia, California in 1869.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Bassett was superintendent and general freight agent of the Northern Division of the Southern Pacific Railroad.

did.unittitle: Dr. L.A. Bauer
R.W. Baxter, Central Pacific Railroad [SF Chronicle photograph, notes on verso]

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Baxter was foreman of Central Pacific's track-laying gang during the construction of the trancontinental railroad. He poses here with the hammer used to drive the golden spike at Promontory Point, Utah as well as the shovel used to turn the first earth in Sacramento.

Columbia Home Guards. Joe Smith [possibly Joseph A. Smith, Aid-de-Camp, with rank of Captain], Gen. Dobie [Brigadier General, Third Brigade A.E. Dobbie], Davies [Brigadier General William A. Davies], Capt. Hooker [Captain Ambrose E. Hooker]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Tuolumne Home Guard and was officially mustered in as Company A, First Infantry Battalion, Third Brigade, on September 10, 1861. A. E. Hooker, a resident of Columbia, who was elected as Captain at the first meeting of the Home Guard, was largely responsible for the organization and equipment of the company and to his efforts was due much of their later success ... Reorganized and mustered in as a unit of the National Guard of California under the title Tuolumne Guard, 4 July 1866." http://www.militarymuseum.org/TuolomneHomeGuard.html

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: California State Archives holds the Militia Companies Records, 1849-1880: http://www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/tf0r29n3x1. Tuolumne Home Guard is filed as Item No. B3410-2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Historical Events & Notable Sayings of the Honored and Lamented U.S. Grant [small round placard by C.D. Mosher, Chicago. Accessioned by Stanford Museum July 20, 1903] ; Rockwood photograph, New York [Accessioned by Stanford Museum July 20, 1903] ; Charles L. Eugene Sullivan [I.W. Taber photograph, San Francisco]

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Possibly Eugene L. Sullivan, who was a commissioner for the Central Pacific Railroad and a former state senator. He was also head of Customs for the Port of San Francisco and was active in civic affairs in the city until his death in 1885.

James Gregg Fallon 1880-1905. Artist of Columbia, Cal.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Fallon was the son of Owen Fallon (http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~caalhn/BIOGRAPHIES/FALLON_Owen.htm), who operated a hotel known as the Fallon House in Columbia, California. James inherited the hotel in 1885 but sold it two years later.
